fields.summary: ELB Doesn't Support Duration-Based and Application-Specific Session Stickiness Policies on the same LB port

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
*Assessment*

When comparing Application-Controlled Session Stickiness between [Eucalyptus Load Balancer|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.2/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_sticky_sessions.html] and [AWS ELB|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/US_StickySessions.html#US_EnableStickySessionsAppCookies], cookie response behavior from Eucalyptus Load Balancer doesn't match AWS ELB.  Two 'Set-Cookie' response headers should be sent back to the client - per [AWS ELB session stickiness documentation|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/TerminologyandKeyConcepts.html#session-stickiness].
{quote}
An application instance must always receive and send two cookies: A cookie that defines the stickiness duration and a special Elastic Load Balancing cookie named AWSELB, that has the mapping to the application instance.
{quote}

*Details*

* header responses from application-controlled session stickiness AWS and Eucalyptus ELB:

_Eucalyptus_
{code}
$ curl -I AppSession-325271821652.eulb.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: gunicorn/18.0
Date: Mon, 27 Oct 2014 14:08:40 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 16633
X-FRAME-OPTIONS: SAMEORIGIN
PRAGMA: NO-CACHE
CACHE-CONTROL: NO-CACHE
Set-Cookie: eucaconsole_; expires=Tue, 28-Oct-2014 02:08:40 GMT; Path=/
{code}

_AWS_

{code}
$ curl -I hasp-euca-626736592.us-east-1.elb.amazonaws.com
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
CACHE-CONTROL: NO-CACHE
Content-length: 16605
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Date: Mon, 27 Oct 2014 13:44:44 GMT
PRAGMA: NO-CACHE
Server: gunicorn/18.0
Set-Cookie: eucaconsole_; expires=Tue, 28-Oct-2014 01:44:44 GMT; Path=/
Set-Cookie: AWSELB=29C7878F06E11CEE2DBB424662F279BF6700DE685339A8D8872D225165646728ECBEFE36FA89C90096A0B92B595FACDA729C607F826948A813E723FC88131568113F1C7188ACFFA9DAB0DC6E814D59F70813E0E980F9AE40B0DD43AE435BCB9B361C30D0E7;PATH=/;EXPIRES=Tue, 28-Oct-2014 01:44:44 GMT
X-FRAME-OPTIONS: SAMEORIGIN
Connection: keep-alive
{code}

_Note: Notice that the AWSELB 'Set-Cookie' header response has the same expiration date as application 'Set-Cookie' header response_
{code}
Set-Cookie: eucaconsole_; expires=Tue, 28-Oct-2014 01:44:44 GMT; Path=/
Set-Cookie: AWSELB=29C7878F06E11CEE2DBB424662F279BF6700DE685339A8D8872D225165646728ECBEFE36FA89C90096A0B92B595FACDA729C607F826948A813E723FC88131568113F1C7188ACFFA9DAB0DC6E814D59F70813E0E980F9AE40B0DD43AE435BCB9B361C30D0E7;PATH=/;EXPIRES=Tue, 28-Oct-2014 01:44:44 GMT
{code}

*Steps*

# Set up a Eucalyptus 4.0.1 Cloud with Load Balancer and Eucalyptus DNS enabled
# Add the [CentOS 6.5 image|http://eucalyptus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/public/centos.raw.xz] from emis.eucalyptus.com
# Launch a Load Balancer image with LB port value '80' and instance port value '8888'.  For example:
{code}
# eulb-create-lb AppSession --listener "lb-port=80, protocol=http, instance-port=8888, instance-protocol=http" --availability-zone Honest
{code}
# Add  application-specific session stickiness policies to the LB.  For example:
{code}
# eulb-create-app-cookie-stickiness-policy --policy-name EucaManagementConsolePolicy --cookie-name eucaconsole_session AppSession
# eulb-set-lb-policies-of-listener AppSession --lb-port 80 --policy-names EucaManagementConsolePolicy
{code}
# Launch an instance from the CentOS 6.5 EMI, and [install the Eucalyptus Management Console |https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0.1/index.html#shared/console_install_centos_rhel6.html] on the instance.
# Register the instance with the Load Balancer.  Make sure that the Load Balancer can communicate with the instance on port 8888.
# Use 'curl', and query the URL of the Load Balancer. For example:
{code}
$ curl -I AppSession-325271821652.eulb.future.euca-hasp.cs.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com
{code}
# Notice the lack of the 'Set-Cookie' header value that contains AWSELB
fields.summary: Eucalyptus Load Balancer Doesn't Add ELB Unique Cookie When Application-Controlled Session Stickiness
fields.environment:
* non-HA, single cluster, Eucalyptus DNS enabled, Load Balancer enabled
** 1 x CLC, UFS, Cloudformation, Eucalyptus DNS
** 1 x UFS
** 1 x UFS, Walrus
** 1 x CC (Managed-NOVLAN), SC (DAS)
** 1 x NC

comments.body: [~spark] Is this something we want to address in 4.2?

I don't necessarily think this is a bug. What http client does is to receive the cookies and simply copy them in subsequent requests. Whether there is 1 or 2 cookie does not have any difference because these cookies are not meant to be consumed by clients. I think the AWS docs emphasize that the clients should be able to handle 2 cookies. If we use 1 cookie, we don't even need to warn people. (cc [~mmunn1])
I will close this as not a bug.
